ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot more than I expected about Chinese history and culture from this overview course. I felt that a lot of the information and connections were condensed well by the professor, which I appreciated. It's definitely tough to have students get a sense of over thousands of years of complex history, culture, philosophy, and literature in one semester, but I feel like this course does well from the ancient Shang Dynasty up to the Eight Nation Alliance.
A broad knowledge of Chinese history, philosophy, literature, art, and tradition.
Chinese literature and history over the dynasties
I learned a ton about major events, people and texts within the Chinese Tradition, things that I should have known prior to the course but unfortunately did not.
Best Chinese literature and history class here at Yale, hands-down. You'll regret it if you don't take it.
We surveyed the literature and philosophical texts in Chinese history. We talked about historical events and why the Chinese tradition is continuous.
A new understanding of the ancient Chinese literary cannon.
chronological knowledge of Chinese art, philosophy, and literature up to the early 20th century.

We read Chinese literature from thousands of years ago (from the Shang Dynasty) to the present modern (Qing Dynasty), analyzing how the timeless tradition has changed and echoed each other. We also close read texts of our choice with essay guidelines and were able to design a creative project that drew upon what we had learned.

I now know much more about Chinese history than I did before, which was practically nothing. I know the order of the Chinese dynasties, important philosophies from each dynasty, and how literature and art changes throughout. Being in the writing section also taught me the basics of close-reading passages.
I gained a better understanding of Chinese history, literature, and culture from the Shang Dynasty all the way to the 20th century.

I learned about early Chinese philosophies. By reading lots of Classical Chinese text, I developed in insight in the evolution of the Chinese literary tradition and the origin of many Chinese cultural values and themes.
history of chinese traditional culture
Survey of Chinese history mostly through the lens of literature.

I learned about the pillars of Chinese thought and literature that have been passed down through a long tradition, from the ancient Shang dynasty all the way to the early Republican period. Through this, we read primary sources and direct works from prominent authors and figures in the Chinese tradition, as well as studied the history to put these important works in context. These ideas and concepts are still relevant to understanding Chinese people, Chinese culture, and China as a country today along with Taiwan and other Chinese-diaspora nations that share this common root.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: I feel like sometimes we didn't really have to go to lecture because it felt like we were being talked at. There were also a lot of readings. Weaknesses: The exams threw me off. I didn't expect them to have such thorough exams because there's so much information being tested that studying is hard. In addition, we also had essays to write as well. The workload is definitely higher than you'd initially expect.

Strengths: Professor Bender is really great! His lectures are super well-organized, and he's great at answering any questions we have. In general, great class. Weaknesses: Might want to reconsider the third essay. First off, the Story of the Stone is super duper long, so we only read a tiny portion of it (which itself is long). On top of that, the articles we could choose from for the third essay about Story of the Stone were extremely difficult to understand. Also, the readings on Lu Xun were only assigned on the last week of class, and the essay wasn't even due a week later, so it was harder to start early. All of this is compounded by the fact that it is the end of the semester, so it is in general chaotic. A better third essay might be to look at readings from earlier so we aren't scrambling towards the end, or to make the essay look back and reflect on the general themes of the class.

Strengths: Luke Bender is a great lecturer and the content is so interesting
Weaknesses: way too many assignments

I think this course was incredibly well-designed and taught, from Professor Bender to the TF sessions. The only downside was that at times, it was difficult to get a strong discussion going in section, but that seems to be a function of a lecture, often.
Best Chinese literature and history class here at Yale, hands-down. You'll regret it if you don't take it.

Strengths: Professor Bender is a great lecturer. He is clear, organized, and sometimes humorous. He is also happy to meet with students during office hours. The readings are great, although sometimes they are a bit long. The sections are helpful. I can't think of any significant weaknesses.

The strengths of this course were Professor Bender! He is an amazing lecturer and makes any topic exciting. The weaknesses of this course was the overwhelming amount of material we were asked to prepare for the midterm but most notably the final.
Readings and lectures were super engaging, Canvas page was really well-organized. The only weakness might be that the non-WR discussion sections were not super engaging.

The strengths are definitely Professor Bender's passion for teaching Chinese literature and the detailed slides.Also, the essays were spaced in a way that helped facilitate our understanding of the content while allowing us enough time to deeply analyze and draw insightful ideas from what we were learning to write. I also loved the option of the creative project - I had a lot of fun with it! I also liked that there was a lecture and a section where we could more closely engage with the TF.
I really enjoyed the lectures, and sections were very helpful. The Chinese section was tailored so that the material was relevant and engaging, while also very manageable.

I enjoyed reading the variety of text that was assigned for class and the discussion sections often involving lots of engaging and interesting conversations. The weakness of the class is that is not much guidance on the writing prompts and a clear rubric or guideline we should follow for the essays.
engaging material and lectures
Professor Bender is a great lecturer, and Professor Liu is also a great section leader. Topics connect to each other well.
Very interesting reading and lecture materials. I was excited to come to class each day I had it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I'd recommend if you want a crash course on Chinese history and culture that you may not have been exposed to before. Our course covered things like different forms of Chinese opera and play, Song porcelain, famous landscape paintings, modern Chinese philosophers, ancient Chinese philosophers and scholars, and even some music. It was pretty enjoyable if you have a genuine interest in such things. If you don't want that much work though, I'd say this course's engagement is higher than the average Chinese class because of the readings of ancient texts.
Yes! You learn so much about Chinese philosophy and history and everything. Also, you will finally get to know Confucius better.
Yes but the TAs grade harshly and give unclear feedback

I would definitely recommend it. I think the material was fascinating, taught incredibly well (Professor Bender's lectures were always well done), and the material is incredibly important to understanding China and East Asia. Also for any student who primarily has focused on the Western tradition in any way, this course is great for expanding horizons.
Best Chinese literature and history class here at Yale, hands-down. You'll regret it if you don't take it.
Yes, if you are interested even slightly in Chinese culture. Professor Bender is an excellent lecturer. You do not have to know any Chinese for this class.
I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in Chinese literature and the development of ancient societies.
Absolutely!

Yes! If you have any interest in Chinese literature whatsoever take this class, Professor Bender is an amazing lecturer and you'll get to learn so much about both the history and the literature of China. We also go on a field trip to the Art Gallery which is a highlight of the semester.
Yes, but be wary of how much information is being taught and the amount of work that must be put in towards writing your essays.
Yes! I loved this course, would highly recommend.

I would highly recommend this class if youre really interested in Chinese history, early philosophy, and reading Chinese text. We learn a lot about the origins of a lot of cultural themes, icons, and values that originated from the dynastic times which are still very prevalent today.
yes! very interesting course with an excellent professor
Yes, great way to get a broad understanding of Chinese history.

I would highly recommend this course to another student! Professor Bender is one of the best lecturers I have come across, and he does a fantastic job of synthesizing the class material together and providing a clear flow of material.
Yes, I would. It is an incredible opportunity to learn about Chinese culture and the instruction is just fantastic!
